item.title: Absolute space
item.description: The Cartesian body motion of a body is a change of relation to the bodies that surround it. concept of inertia a body’s motion wil be preserved unless caused to deviate from its path so not a function of its spatial relations to other bodies but of its causal relation The Newtonian body a body’s motion is not a function of its spatial relations to other objects but rather of whether forces are impressed on it.

item.title: Mechanics (Core 1)
item.description: Vectors Notations the basis is the set of unit vectors from which all others are built perpendicular axes normally have basis vectors $\boldsymbol{\hat{i},\hat{j},\hat{k}}$ helpful to remember: i = 8 o’clock, j = 4 o’clock, k = 12 o’clock (standard) this is right-handed axes (anti-clockwise) $\boldsymbol{\hat{a}} = \frac{\boldsymbol{a}}{\left|a\right|}$ Components $\theta$ taken from x-axis $a_x = a\cos{\theta}$ $a_y = a\sin{\theta}$ $\tan{\theta} = \frac{a_y}{a_x}$ $\left|a\right| = \sqrt{a_x^2+a_y^2}$ 3D components pretty much compliant with 2D and 1D examples, but the concept of an e might be harder to visualise, we rely on the unit vectors as it’s a much easier system.
